Award.AbstractNarration:
Transforming Teaching Through Implementing Inquiry (T2I2) is a full research and development project that explores the use of cyberinfrastructure to significantly enhance the delivery and quality of professional development (PD) for grades 8-12 engineering, technology, and design educators. The goal of the project is to study whether the use of highly interactive cyberinfrastructure increases this target audience's: 1) understanding of engineering design concepts and ability to effectively teach them 2) understanding of how to address student learning needs 3) ability to manage, monitor, and adjust the learning environment 4) use of self assessment to enhance teaching ability and 5) engagement in a community of practice. These issues are of particular interest because of the limited resources in place to prepare pre-service engineering and CTE teachers, as well as a lack of in-service PD.

The content for the PD is grounded in the materials and processes of two projects reviewed by the National Research Council's (NRC) report review committee: Technology Education: Learning by Design for Middle Schools" and "Engineering by Design for High Schools." By incorporating an object-oriented generic system design (learning objects), the cyberinfrastructure is set to be reusable, adaptable, and scalable. These learning objects allow for customization of the learning experience, whereby learning facilitators or learners themselves can configure the system based on their specific needs. Delivering learning objects in an online framework enables teachers to develop and grow in a network community.

A mixed methods approach is used to determine effects of professional development. Student achievement is measured by comparing each site's state assessments in the following areas: the curriculum's technology, engineering, and design assessment, end-of-grade mathematics assessment, and end-of-grade science assessment. Both formative and summative evaluation strategies inform the development and implementation of the project. As such, the project will advance theory, design, and practice in middle and high school engineering, technology and design-based classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transforming Teaching through Implementing Inquiry (T2I2)

The Transforming Teaching through Implementing Inquiry (T2I2) project addressed a general absence of professional development (PD) for Technology and Engineering teachers in grades 6-12 with the creation of a web-based, interactive platform with materials designed to parallel the standards for the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards (NBPTS). The T2I2 project curriculum delivered inquiry-based PD to technology and engineering teachers. This PD increased teachers’ abilities to:

  1. manage, monitor, and adjust the learning environment in their classrooms,
  2. understand engineering design concepts and effectively teach them,
  3. address student learning needs,
  4. use self-assessment to enhance teaching ability, and
  5. engage in a community of practice.

T2I2 was a four-year development project which included material and cyberinfrastructure development, pilot studies, and a field study. Year one focused on planning and producing web-based resources for the T2I2. Using the National Board Certification in Career and Technical Education as a guide, the writing team created content to address best practices in teaching within technology and engineering education. Eighteen learning objects categorized by 4 units were the result of work by a team of experienced educators. These four modules begin with a demonstration lesson, move into fostering teamwork, assessment for learning, and end with documenting accomplishments. Each learning object contains: a) Overview; b) Impact on Learning; c) Procedures in the Classroom; d) Determine Success; e) Check for Understanding; f) Artifact, and g) Appendix. The design and sequencing of these units, based on National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, were modified and improved through an iterative process.  These additions, adaptations, and modifications were based upon student outcomes and teacher implementation experiences.

After completion of the resource development phase, two years were dedicated to pilot testing the learning objects with in-service teachers. Participants were both traditionally trained technology and engineering educators as well as those who obtained licensure through alternative means. As evidence of their learning and practice, participating teachers completed written and video artifacts required upon completion of each unit. These artifacts align to the five research questions discussed above. All participant artifacts were assessed by a nationally board certified teacher using a four-point criterion referenced rubric to measure teacher ability in managing a learning environment, monitoring learning environment, adjusting a learning environment to improve instruction, conducting self-assessment, and contributing to a learning community.

Year two and three pilot data was collected from the assessment of the teacher artifacts and analyzed. Analysis of the pilot data suggests that participation in the T2I2 professional development sequence can support the educator’s ability to monitor, manage, and adjust the learning environment; contribute to the learning community, and increase the teacher’s self-assessment. In project years two and three, the T2I2 learning objects were modified based on usability indicators and outcomes of  Technology and Engineering Education 6-12 classroom teachers.

The fourth year consisted of information dissemination of the findings of the T2I2 project and making the platform available for use by teachers as professional development. This public release involved rebranding the T2I2 project for commercial use. This new platform, STEM Teacher Learning (stemteacherlearning.com), represents the completed research, findings, and revisions of the T2I2 project. Along with the dissemination of the findings and the launch of the commercial product, the investigators have begun to explore avenues and forums for expansion of the T2I2 platform using the principles and format of the current professional development series.
